title: Dynamic Queue Statistics for 61,977 Matches
body:
I found some really interesting data on dynamic queue matchmaking. I think you guys will be interested in it as well. Riot will not tell us the facts but that doesn't mean we can't figure it out ourselves. All credits go to richkcho for doing the statistical analysis. All the below is quoted from his report which is linked at the bottom of this post.

> I amassed 61977 matches which included at least one challenger or master player. The data scraping attempted to obtain around 100 of the most recent ranked matches per player in challenger/master in this case starting from April 23rd. (This would vary based on players activity, inactive players would have older games in their past 100 games compared to a more active player)
> 
> The matches were analyzed to find premades, premades being a group of players who have played at least 10 games together on the same team. There were a total of 1129 games which had at least one 5 man premade. (this might be why Riot doesn't care, matches that include premade 5's statistically speaking are a small minority of matches) The team facing the 5 man premade had the following distribution of premades:
> 
> *  5 solo: 255 (23%)
> *  1 duo, 3 solo: 313 (28%)
> *  2 duo, 1 solo: 58 (4%)
> *  1 trio, 2 solo: 220 (19%)
> *  1 trio, 1 duo: 45 (4%)
> *  1 quad, 1 solo: 168 (15%)
> *  another 5 man premade: 70 (6%)
> 
> I also ran win-rate analysis. The win rates of the 5 man premade vs the other team based on the premade breakdown of the other team is as follows:
> * vs 5 solo: 70% (179/255)
> * vs 1 duo, 3 solo: 58% (183/313)
> * vs 2 duo, 1 solo: 60% (35/58)
> * vs 1 trio, 2 solo: 63% (138/220)
> * vs 1 trio, 1 duo: 53% (24/45)
> * vs 1 quad, 1 solo: 54% (91/168)

> So Riot decided to limit the premade size to three as a band-aid approach to fix the problems elaborated above. The natural question is is this fair?
> 
> I ran the same analysis on the dataset but this time focusing on 3-man premades. There were 8170 games with at least one 3-man premade (excluding any games with 4 or 5 man premade). The breakdown of the premade distributions of teams playing against a team with a 3-man premade were:
>
> * 5 solo: 4012 (49%)
> * 1 duo, 3 solo: 2978 (36%)
> * 2 duo, 1 solo: 548 (7%)
> * a group with a 3-man premade: 632 (8%)
>
> Win rates were as follows:
> * vs 5 solo: 61% (2464/4012)
> * 1 duo, 3 solo: 54% (1604/2978)
> * 2 duo, 1 solo: 52% (386/548)

Tl;dr, Premades play teams of mostly solo players the majority of the time and destroy them.

Full report: https://github.com/richkcho/league_of_tilt/blob/master/other/flaws_of_dynamic_queue.md

replies.body: 5 man teams win 70% of games, I vote that we get solo queue back, sick of losing to teams of toxic brats

In challenger and masters. Where the matchmaking has been terrible, and riot has completely admitted it, to the point where you can no longer make 5 mans at that tier. Dynamic has had several issues at high elo, this is well documented, and admitted. However, none of the statistics mentioned in the opening post apply to the vast, vast majority of players. Run the same analysis on the whole population, or even better, exclude challenger and masters, and you'll see a vastly different set of results.

Ok so open up the riot API so we as players can pull the pre-made data from all levels of play and calculate it, though you know what? that will just show the same problem at plat, gold, and even silver and no differences at bronze.

Hence why riot wont allow us to poll our own pre-made data because they KNOW what it says and it would look very very bad for them.

> 5 man teams of Challenger and Master players win 70% of games against teams that consist of 5 solo players, in a sample size of 255 games in which this occurred.

ftfy

255 is statistically significant. That's not a negligible sample size. The part about 5 solos is important though. 

Also that is games with at least a single challenger or master player. Thus it is very applicable to mid-high diamond. It's definitely a biased sample, but that doesn't mean it isn't as bad for lower tier players. I can think of arguments for why it would be both better and worse. 

In summary - its still completely unacceptable.

> 5 man teams win 70% of games, I vote that we get solo queue back, sick of losing to teams of toxic brats

The quote above does not accurately represent what the data actually shows and what the analysis actually applies to. If my "ftfy" comment was able to get someone to re-read the OP's information to see what it actually says, then my efforts have not been wasted.

> 255 is statistically significant. That's not a negligible sample size. The part about 5 solos is important though.

255 is probably a high enough sample size to find statistically significant information. I just don't want people who come into this thread thinking that the 70% win rate is supported by the thread's title claim of a sample size of 61,977 games.

> Also that is games with at least a single challenger or master player. Thus it is very applicable to mid-high diamond. It's definitely a biased sample, but that doesn't mean it isn't as bad for lower tier players. I can think of arguments for why it would be both better and worse.

Generalization, however, is not something that I think this set of analysis has. Riot has specifically stated that the match maker does not work well within the highest tiers of play. Even if these games sit in mid to high diamond (seems doubtful to me?) then the vast majority of the player base is still not going to be easily generalized with this analysis.

> In summary - its still completely unacceptable.

That would be why there is still work to be done. Do keep in mind though that in the given all of the 61,977 games sampled only 255 of them were actually a 5-man premade against 5 solo players, which equates to **0.4% of the total sample**.

Since when is more than 60 thousand a small sample size? Have you ever taken statistics?
When over 60 thousand games are played a day, that is considered a small sample size. If it were all possible games over the span of a month or two, it wouldn't be considered a small size

> [{quoted}](name=Discount Milk,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=4tsuGXEq,comment-id=00000000000000000000,timestamp=2016-06-16T20:53:41.771+0000)
>
> When over 60 thousand games are played a day, that is considered a small sample size. If it were all possible games over the span of a month or two, it wouldn't be considered a small size

It is the 100 most recent games of each player that are considered. That is a statistically significant number. It is not 1 or two games of random players at random times.
rekt
The total amount of games played does not make 60,00 any smaller.  That is a colossal number of games.
5 mans play against 5 solos only 23% of the time, the other 77% of the time they are against a group with at least one other premade.  This does not constitute a majority.

I just want to point out the fact that you complain about Riot's "stats" yet you are falling into some very big traps for statistical analysis. 

1) **The sample is NOT random at all.** You even admit it's ONLY challenger/master players. So, by that statement, you admit you are trying to do a POPULATION distribution and look at that, which assumptions used for random samples CANNOT be applied.

2) **You are looking at the top .11% of the population.** These are the BEST players in the population and are the fringes of the population. You could even say they are "outliers" in a data set for how much different their skill level is compared to the rest of the population (think SKT skill vs. normal player).

3) **Your data set is TINY when you look at certain "samples" in your data.** A group of 45 games to tell you what the ENTIRE population does? Most statistical analysis samples require AT LEAST 100 to be big enough to not have HUGE issues with potential skewed data and making sure the confidence interval and standard deviation is not large.

4) **RIOT ADMITS THERE IS PROBLEMS IN THIS SMALL SUBSET OF PLAYERS.** So, you are simply proving that what Riot has stated is right? Ok, no one ever argued that Master+ was not an awful place for matchmaking. 

5) If** you want to find out what 95% of the population is facing in Dynamic Que matchmaking, TAKE A SAMPLE OF BRONZE/SILVER/GOLD. **The majority of the population is in Bronze/Silver/Gold, not Master. As you can see with pick/bans and winrates if you look at a breakdown, different divisions have a vastly different meta game. 

This is not to say that the dynamic Que matchmaking is not broken. If we are going to get mad, let's at least use the RIGHT data and fix the RIGHT problems. It's really similar to champion balance: gutting champions does nothing productive because a new champion becomes an issue. Correct nerfs/buffs makes the game balanced, and CORRECT CHANGES to the ranked system will fix it.

**tl;dr: The statistics are misleading. Dynamic Que could very well be that awful at lower elos, but let's actually use correct stats instead of trying to mislead people. Players complain about Riot's misleading stats, don't pull the same crap.**
I don't think the idea is to say DynamicQ is bad, just that it's not very good at high level play. Looking at the notes from author on git hub it certainly looks this way to me.
Well I mean, everyone knew that already. Riot has said that multiple times themselves.

While I have repeatedly tried to use intellectual arguments, people on these boards have shifted all their "elo hell" rants to DQ. It's really quite obnoxious.

it seems to rarely matter what the facts are, they'll cherry pick until it proves the new emo hell DQ is the reason they're not Diamond.
They're not blaming Dynamic Queue because they're not Diamond. They're blaming Dynamic Queue for their match ups.

I agree. Taking a sample of Bronze to Gold would account for about 90% of the population last I checked and that would be more accurate.

Considering that this is League of Legends, I don't think 100 games is enough. It would have to be much greater than that. But since you're only looking at the grouping and not a detailed analysis of each individual game, it isn't as hard as it seems. The problem is trying to find data on those games since it's really hard to collect it yourself.

win rate vs 5 solo: 70% (179/255)

> 
> I'm now curious what lower elo stats look like.  I mean, we now know Riot's stats are intentionally misleading.  Is it possible the popular sentiment of "Dynamic Queue only hurts high elo" is actually false, and affects lower elo as well?

It definitely hurts low elo. You can't say that forcing matchmaking to accept people in groups rather than split them up evenly is going to *help* it. What Riot is trying to sell is that it doesn't *meaningfully* hurt low elo. Who knows if that's true though. I certainly don't trust Riot to give us a straight answer, but that doesn't mean they *can't* be right.
This is old stats. Riot knows this, Its why 4+ premades are disabled in Diamond+. Since then they have made premades match against higher MMR players than any of the individuals of the premade

Go to the report and read what he did on the new 3 max queue. Things are not much better.

This is probably the most important piece of information to those posting in the original post:
> I amassed 61977 matches which **included at least one challenger or master player**. 

* So the data is generally of an elo of Challenger to Master. (If you aren't in that tier of players, the data analysis probably is NOT going to generalize to you.)


* At the highest levels of elo the match making system does not work nearly as well as it does anywhere else. (This is mostly because there aren't enough people of equal rating to actually match against)


Here is probably the second most important piece of information that people seem to be ignoring:
> The matches were analyzed to find premades, premades being a group of players who have played at least 10 games together on the same team. **There were a total of 1129 games which had at least one 5 man premade.**

* The middle set of win rates that are being quoted by the OP are based on 1129 games of Challenger to Master players. (So 1.8% of the total games surveyed)


* The 70% win rate against 5 SOLO PLAYERS is taken from 255 games of the 1129 of games with a 5 man pre-made while. Which equates to this happening 0.4% of time within the given sample. So it doesn't happen all that much.

I want solo stats officially separate from DQ. It just makes no sense to average out rankings anymore than it would make sense to average out all grades in school with no way of getting specifics. If I get a D in Geometry and an A in Algebra, by Riot's logic my ranking would be C+. It's true but also pointless and meaningless due to how ambiguous that is. Don't ruin this game as a competitive endeavor.

I know DQ is a cash grab aimed to get more people invested in the game due to social elements (also why groups get more rewards at the expense of solo players) and because ranked players tend to spend more money on it but if you destroy the game's competitive mode in the process, no one will care anyway eventually. Right now, ranked is basically normals with better matchmaking so the fire to play it as a demonstration of skill is gone and it's hard to take the game as seriously as before. How can we even have a "ladder" system when you can't directly compare players on the same ladder because some might only play 4 mans while others are playing only solo etc.

When you've created a ranked system that even under ideal circumstances with short queue times and 50% winrate for every queue configuration is still meaningless for the primary purpose of a ranked system, you know something's wrong. If you ever reach that, matchmaking will be good but the ladder will still be useless as long as there is no separation between queue configurations for rankings.

"99% of the times there will be premades of the same size and skill in both teams"

Fuck you Riot.

This has not been the case for me.  I soloQ (tm) and most of my games are ether my team having the premade or the other team.  Usually the team with the premade wins if the match snowballs.  But if the match lasts to 35+ minutes then its up in the air.

I also have noticed more 3 man premades are are total crap and should not be playing at the rank/MMR they are put at.

As SoloQ (tm) I find I have to try hard a lot to support these premades.
If the games all included one master's or challenger player then these stats don't actually mean anything to 95% of the player base.

> [{quoted}](name=ThePartyLeader,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=4tsuGXEq,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2016-06-16T20:21:36.657+0000)
>
> If the games all included one master's or challenger player then these stats don't actually mean anything to 95% of the player base.

Yes, they mean something to 100% of the player base since we are supposed to be matched by skill level.

The same ratios would apply since the advantage arises from being in a premade, not skill level.

> [{quoted}](name=Enemy Feeder,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=4tsuGXEq,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2016-06-16T20:28:39.944+0000)
>
> Yes, they mean something to 100% of the player base since we are supposed to be matched by skill level.
> 
> The same ratios would apply since the advantage arises from being in a premade, not skill level.

Not how it works. If you think a bronze premade 5 has the same win rate as a master's premade 5 vs teams of solo player with equal mmr I would say you are gravely mistaken.

There is a reason rito said it was a problem for diamond and up but not other elos. Those premade 5s you are basing this off of could easily be clg, tsm ect also that could sway the scale greatly.

So 5 man with a slightly better communication, coordination and with bad skill against 5 solos with bad skill.

Explain again how is that fair?

> [{quoted}](name=kaltenashes,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=4tsuGXEq,comment-id=0001000000000001,timestamp=2016-06-16T21:05:56.083+0000)
>
> So 5 man with a slightly better communication, coordination and with bad skill against 5 solos with bad skill.
> 
> Explain again how is that fair?

I'm saying it's apples to oranges. You can't look at stats for drastically different groups and assume they are the same. That is not how stats work.

More like navel oranges to tangerines. At the end of the day, it's the same game, the same champions, the same match. Sure, pro players will be able to get proportionally more power out of communication, but even in bronze, it'll still shift the balance in their favor.

> [{quoted}](name=Darien Juranas,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=4tsuGXEq,comment-id=000100000000000100000000,timestamp=2016-06-16T22:08:52.384+0000)
>
> More like navel oranges to tangerines. At the end of the day, it's the same game, the same champions, the same match. Sure, pro players will be able to get proportionally more power out of communication, but even in bronze, it'll still shift the balance in their favor.

Not necessarily a fan of DQ here, but I think you're misinterpreting the point. People aren't arguing that Challenger premades are more successful than Bronze premades when playing against solos, they're arguing that Challenger premades are more likely to face a team of 5 solos than Bronze premades, simply because of player population size (much less likely for there to be a 2nd 5-man premade in Challenger where you have a few hundred players vs. Bronze where you have hundreds of thousands).

In other words, the stats in question isn't the winrate, but the premade vs. solo matchmaking distribution (i.e. the first half of OP's data)

> [{quoted}](name=ThePartyLeader,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=4tsuGXEq,comment-id=000100000000,timestamp=2016-06-16T20:33:23.831+0000)
>
> Not how it works. If you think a bronze premade 5 has the same win rate as a master's premade 5 vs teams of solo player with equal mmr I would say you are gravely mistaken.
> 
> There is a reason rito said it was a problem for diamond and up but not other elos. Those premade 5s you are basing this off of could easily be clg, tsm ect also that could sway the scale greatly.

Bronze 5 premades would have an even higher win rate because the communication advantage is worth even more against players who don't know how to respond to coordination and team play.

As someone who's played with a team of 5 Bronze/Silver players, you overestimate the ability to coordinate and execute even with communication. 

Add to that that it's far more likely to be premade vs premade when you're pulling from ~30% of the playerbase (as oppose to the ~0.07% of the playerbase used for the posted stats) ... Honestly, I doubt any of these stats would hold. With Riot's MMR compensation for premades, it wouldn't surprise me if a 5 Man Bronze team loses more against 5 Solo than they win.

Remember though, bronze is pretty much a hell hole consisting of the worst players in league. 
Catering to those guys isn't the way to go. Which riot tried to do, and now it's failing.

If taken from a lower-ranked division, there would be a much higher percentage of games between two teams of premade 5's (since at Challenger/Master, very few queue up as 5 at all, whereas in Bronze-Gold there are many). Additionally, the win-rate of premade 5's against a team of solos (though a small number of games) would undoubtedly be much lower than 70%.

What this does prove is that Dynamic Queue is not good for the most talented players in the rare occurrences that there are large groups. But it's not nearly as disastrous for the ranks of the majority of players. I wish we could get these stats to confirm it though.

> [{quoted}](name=Mr Fidori,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=4tsuGXEq,comment-id=000100000001,timestamp=2016-06-16T21:23:48.492+0000)

Rito, plz 

premades vs premades, solo vs solos
That is an improvement. The win rate vs team's of 5 solos dropped 70% to 61%.
